lines.name: Git Yer Comeuppance
lines.description: Start far right at the bottom of the 45 degree wall matched on the good sloper. Move up the corner to a dyno, then up and left through some cool moves. Top out.
lines.location: At the far left of the main face.

lines.name: Jason's Traverse
lines.description: Follow the obvious line from right-to-left, or left to right.
lines.location: On the first face you encounter when coming from the main area.

lines.name: The Bandit
lines.description: Start far right on a side pull and a high foot, work your way up to the prow with a big move to a good sloper. Pull over the top.
lines.location: On the first problem you come across, known as the Guardian Boulder

lines.name: Bandito
lines.description: Start far left and follow jugs and edges up to the same good sloper as the bandit. Top out as bandit.
lines.location: On the Guardian boulder's left side.

lines.name: Captain's Arete
lines.description: Start with right hand in the crack and left on the arete. Slap up the near vertical arete with your hand and heel until you feel solid and make the move back right to the jug. Jugs to top out.       Much harder the shorter you are.
lines.location: On the obvious highball arete of the Captain Boulder

lines.name: Captains Crack
lines.description: Start with all hands and feet in the crack and work your way up the crack using a few good side pulls to help. Top out as captains arete.
lines.location: On the right face of the Captain Boulder

lines.name: Captains Slab
lines.description: Start on a bad slopper down low. Work your way up the near vertical face on small holds. Load's of potential for cheese grating.
lines.location: On the left side of the Captain Boulder

lines.name: Don't Blow It
lines.description: Start down in the pit in between a small boulder and the wall. Start with both feet on a ledge, right hand on the arete and left hand on the small side pull sloped edge. Work you hands onto the arete and continue up to a big committing move to a great hold left. Top out staying to the right side of the boulder.
lines.location: As you come around to the captain boulder it is downhill on your left in a pit.

lines.name: Innie
lines.description: Start on the horn same as Outie and work your hand into the crack and too out using the crack only.
lines.location: Uphill from the left end of the faces.

lines.name: Outie
lines.description: SDS on the rail on the left of the crack. Follow the feature up and right to a big throw to a sharp edge to top out.

lines.name: Outie Left
lines.description: SDS as Outie. Traverse up the feature past the crack but head straight up to the lip instead of continuing the traverse. Mantle the top out.

lines.name: Project
lines.description: Start on the same undercling as Slouch. Move left up to a large ledge. Mantle up to a nice lay-back to the top.

lines.name: Slouch
lines.description: Sloper+Ouch=Slouch. Start on the obvious undercling and throw for the dagger covered sloper up and right. It hurts. Continue slapping up painful slopers to the top. A rare great landing.
lines.location: Straight left from the Guardian Boulder on the downhill side of the Steeple Boulder.

lines.name: Steeple Slab
lines.description: Climb the slab climbers left of Steeple Squeeze follow some flakes to a committing move up high.
lines.location: Left slab face of Steeple Squeeze

lines.name: Steeple Squeeze
lines.description: An amazing problem on amazing rock over an amazingly bad landing. Start at the very bottom point of the rock smearing on the slab left with feet. Climb onto the right slap with odd guppy grips until you are fully on the slab right. Work your hands up the arete until you find the good right hand edge out right. Slow your pulse and make some committing moves up high to top out.
lines.location: On the obvious "Steeple" on the Steeple Boulder, opposite the Captain's Arete
lines.protection: Lots of Pads/Spotters bring this from an "x" to "PG13".   Need to toss a rope for the down climb.

lines.name: Sumo Wrestler
lines.description: Wes thinks it should be a 4 star. Start as far left on the sloppy lip as possible. Work your way right to the good centre sloper and top out.

lines.name: Classic Flake
lines.description: Super-classic granite layback flake. The flake fizzles out up high and leads to a scary slab climb the is easier than it looks.

lines.name: Lightning Crack
lines.description: Up right from Yet to be Sober. Obvious Crack.

lines.name: Swig Swag
lines.description: Very fun V1! Work your way up the huge blocks to the main top-out ledge. Hardest moves are up top. Spotter necessary.

lines.name: Yet to be High
lines.description: Same as yet to be sober but instead of the lower flake, traverse across the small seam of tiny crimps. meets yet to be sober at the good jug.

lines.name: Yet to be Sober
lines.description: Start far left on the upwards facing flake. Traverse right and work your way onto the large slopey corner holds. One big move up to the sloped dish and a committing move on a small side-pull crimp will get to you to better holds up top. Top out on the ledge then rappel or climb the next section of easy slab and walk down.

lines.name: The Agony of De-feet
lines.description: Climb easy ground up to the first bolt, following the bolts through progressively harder slab climbing. Finish up at a large tree on the right, or continue up on gear. May want some small pieces to protect the slab, or prepare for runout sport.

lines.name: Aria's Orange Slushy
lines.description: Climb up the sloping corner onto the slabby face at 5.6ish climbing, and follow the orange "slushy" stain on the rock.
lines.location: First route left of the Chimney.
lines.protection: bolted; anchor and rap rings at top

lines.name: Dude, I Think She is the King
lines.description: Climb the slab past 2 small cam placements to a line of bolts.  Go right at the last bolt to a pin in the corner and then back left to a 1" crack which leads to a bolt anchor above the leaning cedar.

lines.name: Father and Son
lines.description: Climb the bolted S-shaped line up the sustained wall to the Metolius rap hangers for the first pitch of Perspective.   This was the first sport climb at Eagle's Nest and was hand drilled while the first ascensionist's father belayed patiently over 2 days (bolts took 30 min. each!)
lines.location: 10 feet right of Perspective at an aspen tree.

lines.name: Father's Day Slab
lines.description: P1: At the large dirty ledge move left past a bolt into a treed gully to gain a slab. Climb the right line of bolts up to anchors. (25m) P2: Continue up past bolts to the left side of the roof to a large ledge sharing the anchor for Lichen It.
lines.location: Same start as for Lichen It.

lines.name: Finger Stinger
lines.description: Climb the first pitch of 5.8 Stairway to Heaven. At the anchors, instead of going up and right (2nd pitch of Stairway to Heaven) go left towards the slight overhang that follows into the thin crack to the top. It is a thin diagonal traverse with good feet leading to the roof. Lay back onto the small ledge on the left side of the small roof, then smear and lay back the thin seam to progress higher into the crack. The uneven crackling has some good handjams in some spots, and some very thin laybacking in others. Fantastic Route to a 2 bolt anchor. Can 5.4 scramble for another 15 meters (50 feet) to the top (look for tat with carabiners on 2x trees for anchoring/repelling).
lines.location: Must climb the first pitch of 5.8 Stairway to Heaven to approach 5.11b Finger Stinger.
lines.protection: Small cams in multiples up to .75. Can use a #2 under roof, but needs extension, or plug smaller gear along the continuous vertical crack instead (just back it up). 2 bolt anchor at the top.

lines.name: Migizi Wazoson
lines.description: Route description by FAist:Pitch one (The Rocks) 5.9, 50ft: Dance up the technical cracks then up the left traverse to the arête beside the steep head wall. Stick-clipping the first bolt is recommended as the crux is low. 8 bolts. You can alternatively climb Tilting Planet and continue to the next pitch.Pitch two (The Waters) 5.9, 88 ft: Crack your way up a deceivingly easy looking slab to a mid slab crux that takes a moment to figure out but feels good when you do. Follow the bolts to some fun moves into a traverse with lots of great holds all the way to the anchor for a relaxing finish. 9 bolts.Pitch three (The Forests) 5.4, 40ft: Casual pitch that heads up a fun and easy little crack to Snake Ledge. Easy but mossy walk onto the ledge. 4 bolts.Pitch four (The Skies) 5.6, 50ft: One of the best pitches on the route that follows more slab on great holds and great feet with an even more spectacular view. Wonderful way to finish it off. 6 bolts.Note: You can combine pitches 3 and 4 easily.Finish the route off by rapping back down from the top of pitch-four to the top of pitch-two. From here rap down through some trees that part to allow passage down to the top of pitch one. Rap to the ground from here.
lines.location: Located left of central of all the bolted routes on the wall, roughly at the right end of the main parking lot.

lines.name: Perspective
lines.description: P1: Take the low angle offwidth crack up past some ledges to a large belay ledge with a geocache.    P2: Go around the right side of the large flake, and climb the crack to the top.
lines.location: First route in from the approach trail next to the auto parts store. Obvious large crack on the corner.
lines.protection: Standard rack up to 4", a newer leader might want a 5" piece for some of the crux offwidth moves.

lines.name: The Swiftly Tilting Planet
lines.description: Follow the bolted line up a steep thin slab to rappel anchors. The hardest parts should be the start and at the 4th bolt.

lines.name: The B Bent Over
lines.description: Start on Screaming Blue, go left on bolts straight up.

lines.name: Bright Green Guru
lines.description: Fingercrack, Climb the flake to the fingercrack. Move right at its end to another crack.

lines.name: I Did it in Heels
lines.description: Hand crack to offwidth before anchors.

lines.name: John Be Careful
lines.description: Slopey pockets
lines.protection: Bolts   Shares anchors with Screaming Blue.

lines.name: Kim is a Hag
lines.description: Low crux, hidden pocket.
lines.protection: Bolts   Finish on Tiny Kingdom anchors

lines.name: Manual Labour
lines.description: Pumpy flaky layback, with a stout crux.

lines.name: Martyr's Shrine
lines.description: Very thin crack beside Manual Labour.

lines.name: Motley Crue
lines.description: Last sport route on the wall. Very slopey.

lines.name: Red Amanda
lines.description: Difficult start to more of the same.

lines.name: Screaming Blue Rancheros
lines.description: Climb the left bolt line to anchors.

lines.name: Short Sharp Shock
lines.description: Barely exists, just right of Motley Crue.
lines.location: Had 4 bolts (sleeves still visible)   No anchors.

lines.name: Swindle! It's A Swindle!
lines.description: 3m left of Under the Volcano.

lines.name: The Tiny Kingdom of Kanga Tarsis
lines.description: Short Crack on the right side of Berlin, first route when entering the crevice.

lines.name: To Kill a Mockingbird
lines.description: Crank hard to anchors.

lines.name: Under the Volcano
lines.description: Corner start, go left to good holds, work the crux.  Run out to 3rd bolt.

lines.name: Welcome to Berlin
lines.description: Originally a one-bolt trad climb, the addition of new bolts and anchors have made this a significantly better route.

lines.name: Unknown
lines.description: Starts off with a couple of pockets to the left of the crack, and provides a satisfying crimp before moving into some bigger holds. The start can be graded up if you choose to stay to the right of the anchors and tackle the excellent crack.
lines.location: About 600 yards in you will come to a small canyon, where a massive boulder has separated from the main cliff.      This route is set to the very left side of the small canyon.
lines.protection: Only 3 draws needed, the first is set a little high and can be set by rapelling, or by climbing on the left side to reach it. It is best to top out or you can use the two bolts set at the top for a rapell.

lines.name: Unknown 2
lines.description: Ideally you start on the crack in the middle, with some big gaps and nasty little crimps.  Then a little higher you have more crack to work with, but with little around it, and next to nothing for the feet.  For an easier start, you can start on the barn door to the right, and then finish in the middle.
lines.location: This is in the middle of the bend crack.  The top is easily identified by the two bolts, and there is a trail to the bottom that is easy to find.
lines.protection: 2 Bolts at the top or trees can be used to anchor for the top rope.  Some day I hope to bolt this route.

lines.name: Unknown 3
lines.description: The Climb starts with a beatiful flake to lay back on, and then gets spotty about half way up. Then you can go left for a significant challenge, or right onto the dihedral for an easy finish.
lines.location: About 600 yards in you will come to a small canyon, where a massive boulder has separated from the main cliff.      This route is set to the middle - right side of the small canyon.
lines.protection: 3 Bolts, ok top anchors, but easier to top out. The first clip is ridiculously high, and the second clip is only necessary if you go left.    Note that the top of the barn door sounds hollow, and flexes a little. As such, belaying from away and to the right is recommended.

lines.name: Walk in the Park
lines.description: Big holds and several ledges make this walk in the park a satsfying feel good warm up.  The start has a bit of a mantle, and the end has a small outcropping to get over, but otherwise, it is a comfortable dihedral, with lots of options.
lines.location: In the canyon area of the bend, about 600 yards from the road, tops out at the top of the trail to the bottom.
lines.protection: Top Rope for now, though you can lead it if you use the unusual bolt pattern of the climb next to it.

lines.description: Nice climb with a burly 5.8 finish. Or step down and left for the 5.7 ramp (not recommended).   Pitch 1 20m - Follow the ramp near the bottom of the easy way down around a bulge to a belay ledge.   Pitch 2 15m - Climb up then step right onto a slab with a crack. Follow this to the overhang above.   Pitch 3 10m - Pull the overhang (recommended) or step down and left and follow the ramp to the top (not recommended). Also possible to exit right (also not recommended).
lines.location: Takes the obvious ramp near the bottom of the easy way down gully.

lines.name: Afternoon Delight
lines.description: No text - use the 'Improve This Page' link to add something useful!

lines.name: Birthday Ridge
lines.description: This easy climb follows a very easy ridge. Its moderate grade make it a great climb to show a non climber what the fuss is all about.
lines.location: Follows a prominent ridge in a huge corner using the picture in the online guidebook it is impossible to miss. Carry double ropes of the rappel.
lines.protection: Most belays are bolted. A single rack of cams and nuts plus double ropes for the rappel. Anchors are bolted.

lines.name: Boris' Route
lines.description: Perhaps the best 5.5 at Bon Echo.   Pitch 1 20m - ascent the trace of a ramp to a wall featuring black cokey rock and continue up the wall and ramp to an obvious belay ledge.   Pitch 2 25m - continue up the ramp to a small sloping ledge with two bolts.   Pitch 3 25m - move up and left to a large ledge below an overhang. Pull the overhang and belay at two bolts.
lines.location: 25m north of Birthday Ridge. Belay 2m above the water level.
lines.protection: Generally good placements with a few pitons and bolts.

lines.name: Conclusion
lines.description: Pitch 1: Start from a low ledge, traverses low underneath a slight overhang then up the ramp moving up and left until you move left and climb up a short headwall over a mantleshelf to the first belay. About 90 ft.   Pitch 2: Follow diagonally up and left and then move left underneath the overhang then up the   corner over some biggish blocks to the trees.
lines.location: The climb starts about 25m south of   Yellow Groove and follows the next diagonal line of weakness.

lines.name: Cool Corner
lines.description: Pitch 1 - 25m - Climb up and diagonally right past a small cedar tree then follow the crack to a belay on the right side of the Birthday Ridge slab.   Pitch 2 - 40m - Climb the corner to where you can escape onto the slab above. Climb up until it merges with Birthday Ridge at the top.

lines.name: The Entertainer
lines.description: Step off the boat and onto a small ledge.  You can build a belay right here, though it's probably easier to scramble up for 5 meters to a larger ledge with more opportunities for gear.  P1 (5.7?) From the large ledge, traverse up and right on mediocre rock (i.e., beware of loose blocks) with well spaced gear.  After 10 meters, you will find yourself at a crack below the left side of the pillar.  We climbed straight up from here for approximately 15 meters, passing a blank spot before reaching the base of the pillar, where the climbing eases up.  Build a gear anchor and belay atop the pillar.  P2 (5.9) Up and left from the belay is a finger crack that continues for 2-3 body lengths.  Have your nuts and small cams ready and fire away!  Once the crack is below you, start traversing left and slightly up, passing a piton or two and an awkwardly placed bolt.  You are aiming for a small tree in a left angling overhang.  Above the tree is a small ledge with a nest of old rusty pitons...and two brand new 1/2" bolts.  Belay here.  P3 (5.?) Climb up then left, or left then up, or diagonally past a bulge 2 meters above the belay.  Continue up varied climbing for 10 meters to gain a large ledge.  From here I'm not sure where the route is supposed to go; I'll describe how we finished.  Scramble left over a large tree, then up until just below a small overhang.  Pulling the roof and you're done.  There are a few large bolts on the ground 7 meters from the cliff edge for a belay.
lines.location: Starts approximately 100 meters right of a small talus slope that marks a break in the cliff.  The route stays to the left of a large overhang.  There is a large pillar 1/3 of the way up the cliff that looks like it will topple off any day now.  The first pitch ends atop this pillar.

lines.name: Fanny Hill
lines.description: Pitch 1 35m - Move left and up onto large blocks then up to a large ledge. Traverse right and climb up the crack to a large stance.   Pitch 2 18m - Climb the steep wall on the left, moving up and right over a series of platforms to the obvious ramp.   Pitch 3 30m - Climb the easy ramp and exit via the overhang or through the shrubs.
lines.location: 33m right of Compulsion and 45m left of Sweet Dreams.
lines.protection: Generally good gear placements. Watch for loose rock.

lines.name: Formication
lines.description: Climb the left side of the slab to the a two bolt belay at the top. 30m      Alternatively, climb the centre of the slab past a single bolt. 5.8
lines.location: Rather sparse gear, especially when climbing the direct variation.

lines.name: French Form
lines.description: Climb the slabby ramp via the corner to a set of bolts midway. Continue up the ramp/corner to a ledge with a large cedar and anchor bolts on the right. (Easily combined with pitch 1). Move the belay a few meters back to a steep wall (bolts). Follow a lightning bolt crack to a small roof, and either step right and around at 5.4 or continue straight up (better) at 5.6.

lines.name: Front of the Pinnacle
lines.description: The crux of this route is a spooky step from the pinnacle. This is what also makes this route so good. Exhilarating exposure on the 2nd pitch will have you laughing the whole way.
lines.location: Starts on a large ramp and follows it to a pinnacle where you belay for the infamous Pinnacle pitch. Great route!! A must do.
lines.protection: Long slings. Small rack of cams and nuts

lines.name: Garden Wall
lines.description: Rarely climbed.   Pitch 1 35m - Climb the ramp to a small belay stance.   Pitch 2 27m - Follow the ramp to the top.   Pitch 3 35m - Continue upwards through easy terrain and shrubbery.
lines.location: Second ramp from the north end of the cliff.

lines.name: Inferno
lines.description: This climb is somewhat atypical for Bon Echo because there's no routefinding skills required.  Simply locate the clean cut dihedral and climb it!  P1: (5.9+) Scramble up easy terrain and clip a bolt before pulling over a roof.  Another 10 meters of moderate, but slightly runout climbing puts you on a ledge below the obvious corner.  There is no pro for a ways leading up to this ledge, so make sure your gear here is solid.  Fire the obvious crux using a less than obvious sequence to gain good holds in the crack above you.  After finishing the corner, continue scrambling up nice cracks and blocks on easier terrain for 10 meters and belay at a stance atop a block.  P2: (4th) Downclimb off the other side of the block and continue up and left to the top of the cliff.
lines.location: To find the start, walk left for 20-30 m from Knob Hill.  The route ascends a clean dihedral, which is directly below a blank face.  A bolt 5 meters off the ground marks the start.  To descend, take the "easy way down."  In other words, follow small trails climbers left from the top of the route, always following the leftmost path.  The trails are faint at times, but as you pass a bluff and start to lose elevation, the trail will become well defined.  At one point, you will scramble down a steep slab for 10 meters.  A short jaunt will bring you back to your packs.
lines.protection: Standard rack including small nuts and a black alien (or equivalent) for the crux and a #4 camalot for the belay.

lines.name: Jerry's Route
lines.description: Rarely climbed.   Pitch 1 40m - Climb through the forest until you get to the ramp.   Pitch 2 40m - Climb the ramp.   Pitch 3 10m - Continue up the ramp to the top.
lines.location: First right leaning ramp from the north end.

lines.name: Knob Hill
lines.description: Start at a clearing in the trees, about 5m north of the narrows, beneath an obvious tree about 20m up.   Pitch 1 - 20m - Climb up the steep face on good holds to a tree.   Pitch 2 - 25m - Move left and up to the huge ledge.   Pitch 3 - 20m - Traverse right (crux) and continue straight up on good holds to the top.

lines.name: Mac's Book
lines.description: Climb the open book and slab to the top.
lines.location: Climb 10m up from the top of Formication and then cross right to the obvious open book.

lines.name: Mooning Boris
lines.description: Links the first pitch of Boris' Route with the third pitch of Moonday. Pitch 2 involves a traverse left across a grassy ledge and scramble to a belay ledge. Lichen the lichen.

lines.name: One Pine
lines.description: A splendid route for beginners.   Pitch 1 - 40m - Belay from the ledge 10m up, climb near or on the outside edge, move up to a wide ledge with a good belay.   Pitch 2 - 28m - Go more or less straight up.   Pitch 3 - 40m - Climb up and move right to an obvious crack below the "pine" tree. Climb the crack and scramble to the bolted belay above.
lines.location: 120m north of the easy way down, at the bottom of a major ramp.
lines.protection: Generally good gear placements with a few pitons.

lines.name: Paradise Lost
lines.description: Pitch 1 20m - Climb up behind the flake then move left and ascent past a bolt and slight right to a large pine tree.   Pitch 2 30m - Climb the ramp to the slabs and continue up the slabs to a belay stance.   Pitch 3 20m - Climb the slab to the top.
lines.location: 10m left of the easy way down.
lines.protection: Generally good gear. Large cams helpful. Can combine pitches 1 and 2.

lines.name: Persuasion
lines.description: A traverse connecting Top Secret and Ottawa Route.
lines.location: Begins at the first belay station of Top Secret.

lines.name: Red Groove
lines.description: An impressive route for beginners.   Get out of the boat and onto the belay ledge (crux). Climb the corner and chimney until forced onto the face by a constriction. Continue to the top.
lines.location: 30m north of the easy way down.

lines.name: The Rose Tattoo
lines.description: Pitch 1. 15m Climb directly up the wall to a comfortable belay stance or continue to the top.   Pitch 2. 35m Move right past a piton up good holds on a left facing corner system before moving right at the top. A variation clips a bolt on Old Faithful near the top and continues up the corner system. Frequently done in one pitch.
lines.location: Start between the narrows and Vertigenous where there are very few trees between the wall and the talus slope.

lines.name: Saturday Night and Sunday Morning
lines.description: Rarely climbed.   Pitch 1 35m - Climb the ramp to an small belay stance.   Pitch 2 20m - Step right and climb up the face above (crux).   Pitch 3 20m - Traverse right and climb up the left side of a pinnacle. Belay on the other side.   Pitch 4 25m - Take any one of many possible finish to the top.
lines.protection: Generally good gear placements. Lots of lichen.

lines.name: The Slab
lines.description: The first pitch provides enjoyable climbing on small holds. The remainder of the climb is disappointing so it is common practice to rappel after the first pitch.
lines.protection: Bolted rappel station at the top of first pitch.

lines.name: Sunday Delight
lines.description: Climb the ramp to the top. 30m
lines.protection: Poor gear lower down but improves further up.

lines.name: Sweet Dreams
lines.description: A Bon Echo classic, hands down.  p1: Scramble up the slab easily to its end, sticking towards the right side. Gear anchor. 5.3 p2: Move out left onto the face (look down, it's a fantastically exposed stance) and traverse left on good feet and somewhat crimpy hands. Use the pitons if you want, but at sometimes 50+ years old, they have a reputation for failure. Back them up. Continue to a right-facing corner and move up to a large ledge. Gear anchor (a variety of pitons are available as well). 5.6-5.7 p3: The big one. Move up the wall to climber's right on the ledge. Clip the bolt a few metres up, towards the end of the crux. The difficulty tapers off a bit, but is fairly sustained. Follow the weakness first up and slightly left to a tree, then up and right to the top. Belay on gear on a big ledge or continue to the top. 5.9+, realistically 10a/b at the crux.
lines.location: Sweet Dreams starts on the first pronounced slab ramp from the North end of the cliff.
lines.protection: Standard rack to #2 Camalot. Full set of nuts.

lines.name: Top Secret
lines.description: Rock fall has altered this route. The new crux is protected with bolts.   Pitch 1 27m - Climb up right, then through the newly exposed rock and move left and up to a small ledge.   Pitch 2 18m - Step up and right and move further right onto the ramp. Go leftwards up the ramp.   Pitch 3 20m - Scramble up to the top. Try to find the "secret" break in the rock at the top to unlock the best part of the route.
lines.location: Start at the top of the scree covered buttress 25m above the lack.

lines.name: Vertigenous
lines.description: Start below a large cedar tree on a ledge a third of the way up the wall.
lines.location: Bolted anchor at top of first and third pitch.

lines.name: Winking Crack
lines.description: Pitch 1 6m - Follow the obvious left-leaning crack over a bulge to a ledge with a cedar tree, below a leaning crack at the back of an overhang.   Pitch 2 25m - Climb the strenuous finger crack (crux) to a ledge with a cedar tree. Climb the overhang to the top.
lines.location: Starts near the bottom of the easy way down.

lines.name: Womb At The Top
lines.description: Pitch 1 35m - climb up onto a block with a bush. Go up and left to a small tree then up and right to a sickly looking tree. Go up and right into the overhanging cleft known as the "womb". Most parties link the second pitch which scrambles up 10m to a bolted anchor.
lines.location: 70m north of the narrows. Take the easy way down.

lines.name: Yellow Groove
lines.description: Start at the first diagonal ramp south of Black Groove.   Rock fall (2011?) obliterated the first belay ledge. Climb the obvious fault, struggle behind the cedar and continue to the top. Watch for loose rock. 45m
lines.protection: Bolted anchor at the top. Generally good gear placements.

lines.name: Angel's Crest
lines.description: Sit start and climb the right face of the arete
lines.location: Behind boulder Malamute at the right of Dreamcatcher's route

lines.name: Beautiful Odyssey
lines.description: SDS matched on a good block with choice of feet. Follow the overhang to the right using ledges and increasingly slopey holds, top out on the arete at the apex of the overhang. Be wary of a block that is coming loose near the bottom of the arete as many people used this hold to move through the crux of the problem.      From the SDS move left and up the slab for the easier, but drier "Some Beautiful Things Remain"
lines.location: Coming down the trail from the Gateway and Nine-Tenths areas this problem is located on the right, just off the path (on the backside of the Malaria boulder).
lines.protection: Pad if desired, more importantly to keep your feet dry as this boulder is located at the edge of the swamp.

lines.name: Blackfly
lines.description: Start on the left side of the slightly overhanging arete with a pinch for the right hand and a small edge for the left. Climb up the arete staying on the left side. Make use of the right facing corner and most likely a very high step for the right foot. While the crux is likely pulling off the high step the topout is slopey so be prepared to mantel it out.
lines.location: On the Nine-Tenths boulder, on the same face as Bullfighter's Friend. The starting holds for Blackfly are on the right arete while Bullfighter starts to the left.   Downclimb the prominent crack on the trail-facing side of the boulder.
lines.protection: A pad should be sufficient, a spotter if the topout bothers you.

lines.name: Bottom Up
lines.description: Sit start and climb the blunt areteDépart assis et grimper l'arête.
lines.location: The arete on the right detached bloc of GatewayL'arête sur le petit bloc détaché de Gateway

lines.name: The Bullfighter's Friend
lines.description: SDS with hands matched on the bottom ledge in the series of "steps". Move up the obvious line trending towards the right. Various beta exists but most includes using the left facing corner and making a stretch to the sloping lip. Once established on the lip throw a heel up and mantle over the top.      A similar line "Ambassador of Kick-Yer-Assiter" (FA Denny Wong) follows the stepped edges but eliminates the lip, instead moving through the left facing corner and topping out further right.       Each variation is worth a try, these problems had previously been considered the "benchmark" for v4 in the area, but more recently both have been re-evaluated as V3. Might feel somewhat stiff for a 3 to some, especially if you don't have the reach to simply stick the lip from the blocky steps.
lines.location: Located on the backside of the Nine-Tenths boulder, the boulder following The Gateway along the trail. Pretty prominent line on a great boulder.
lines.protection: pad and spotter, the landing is decent but try not to flail off the top.

lines.name: Castaway
lines.description: Sit start on a crimp in the small left facing corner and climb up
lines.location: On the face of West Nile between a small roc close of the pond and the path from Nine-Tenths

lines.name: Coordination Tongue
lines.description: Vertical wall. Start on two small crimps slightly right of the middle of the wall. Move up and top out.
lines.location: On the Marsh boulder, located on the side facing the marsh. There is a log platform preventing you from sinking into the marsh. Getting down you go to the other side of the boulder.

lines.name: Cruxifixion
lines.description: Start on a prominent flake with many options for feet. Move straight up through a cluster of holds (including a pinch, crimps, and an undercling) avoiding the good holds further to the right. Aim for the jug directly above this cluster that seems so close, and yet...      The first three ascents of this problem were all done in very different styles, so play around with different beta on the various holds until something clicks for you. Surprisingly all versions feel about V5.      Since the first few ascents one or two footholds have broken/crumbled making this problem more challenging. I've tried two of the three betas I know of and both were somewhat harder, I'm assuming the undercling beta (used for the FA) is similarly changed.
lines.location: Starts on the prominent flake to the left of Westward Ho! on the West Nile Boulder.   As this problem is on the swamp facing side of the boulder it may be largely inaccessible once the snow melts and the water level rises.
lines.protection: A pad or two, the landing is somewhat uneven.

lines.name: Dreamcatcher
lines.description: Climb the face anywhere between the off-width crack and the left side of the face.
lines.location: Boulder Malamute close of the cliff juste at the left of the indication "Mid-Cliff"

lines.name: Fear of Porcupines
lines.description: SDS with right hand on a low thumbcatch sidepull and left higher up on a sloping edge with bad smeary feet. Make a couple moves up through sloping edges to grab the lip. Make a somewhat difficult and committing mantel to finish.
lines.location: Located on the backside of the Phobia boulder, to the left of the "pit". Other problems start on a prominent ledge that runs across the boulder, the starting holds for this problem are to the right of this ledge.
lines.protection: pad over the jumbled rock landing

lines.name: Featured Press
lines.description: Start on the obvious crimp 6ft right of the arete. Pull on with difficulty and climb the slab to the top.A sit start is  possible with a lower crimp a few feet to the right and goes about the same grade.
lines.location: In the middle of the Nine-Tenths boulder on the slab face.

lines.name: From Capetown to Cairo
lines.description: Stand start with a left hand undercling and right hand sidepull on the face (left) side of the arete. Make a move up through a crimp and edges to top out at the top of the arete. The crux seems to be making the first move without your feet popping off the wall. Stay to the left of the arete as the right side is another problem.      One of a few decent (and easier) problems on the Africa Boulder that isn't height dependent.
lines.location: Start on the far right hand side of the Africa Boulder.

lines.name: Gate Traverse
lines.description: SDS as for Gateway Arete and move up the arete to gain the obvious sloping ledge which traverses right along the length of the boulder. Various options and contrivances exist but for the V1 version continue along this edge until it ends at the right-facing corner. Climb up using edges to an easy mantel.      Another option is to traverse the edge to about midway on the boulder and fire up to the lip linking into Put All Your Fears To Rest. This involves a satisfying dyno move and a slightly more challenging mantel.
lines.location: On the trail facing side of the Gateway Boulder.

lines.name: The Gate
lines.description: SDS on a left hand pinch and right hand edge. Move directly up through sloping edges, crux seems to be sticking a small slot/crimp. Good movement on a slightly overhanging boulder makes for a nice warmup.
lines.location: Located on the left hand side of the first boulder encountered (the gateway boulder) if you take the new trail below the cliff and talus.
lines.protection: pad if you like, the landing is good and the problem not very high

lines.name: Gatekeeper
lines.description: SDS on the large incut ledge under the short roof. Using sloping holds go direct over the lip and up the crack to a top out jug. Careful footwork makes this go fairly easily.
lines.location: The first boulder encountered when following the main path below the talus and alongside the swamp. Found to the left of the trail just before heading up the slight rise that goes to the Gateway Boulder. The start hold is located under the obvious roof.

lines.name: Gateway Arete
lines.description: SDS on the left side of the Gateway Boulder at the base of the arete. Move up large edges, some slightly sloping, to the lip, top out. Decent climbing but very short.
lines.location: On the far left of the trail facing side of the Gateway Boulder, the first obvious boulder encountered if following the new trail below the cliff and talus.

lines.name: Gatineau Special
lines.description: Start low to the left of Ken's Super Slab on a low undercling and power out and right to some slopey crimps before topping out on the slab. Pay attention to your feet on the starting moves because it feels much harder if you don't place them correctly. The undercling move is almost all bicep...
lines.location: Left and underneath of Ken's Super Slab

lines.name: The High Road
lines.description: SDS on the jug flake under the roof as per November. Move up and left until you hit the sloping lip. Where November uses the huge jug at the lip and then tops out through the blocky corner, High Road traverses left along the lip using slopes, crimps, and powerful heels to top out at the far left side of the boulder. While it might be possible to top out at any point, fight through the forearm pump until you reach edges and jugs to top out on the left side.      A great problem that feels less contrived than it sounds, the movement is excellent and the length is somewhat unique for Calabogie. An edge about a foot above the lip has been cleaned/dug out fairly recently which may make the problem easier, so if you want to do the original line just avoid this seam.      This problem traverses along the lip of the boulder, the heavily chalked sloping, diagonal ledge running under the roof is the Low Road V8, which looks excellent but is also harder.
lines.location: Starts as per November under the roof of the Frigid Cave Boulder, behind and to the left of the Gateway Boulder
lines.protection: a few pads or a spotter to move one in order to cover the blocks resting under the cruxes.

lines.name: Hispanic Panic
lines.description: Stand start on good foot holds and move up the slab using a couple crimps, the obvious ledge, and the smooth arete.
lines.location: On the back of the Gate boulder, the obvious slab.

lines.name: Horde Juggernaut in the Fog
lines.description: Stand start on crimps and/or the blocky arete with choice of slippery feet. Make some moves on perfect (if slightly sharp) crimps for the left hand and slap up the arete with your right. Grap a left facing corner above the lip and top out. Excellent problem which requires some technique.      Eliminating the arete and beginning on crimps a bit further left (right hand is on the crimp used for the left hand when starting Horde Juggernaut...) is Coordination Tongue (V6)       This face catches far more sun than any other at Calabogie, making it an ideal spot on cold days, but the crimps get slick quickly in the summer.
lines.location: Located on the swamp facing side of the Marsh Boulder. From the clearing in the highball area head through the passage to the right of the Apathy Boulder (the scooped slab with a diagonal crack running across the top). The Marsh Boulder is to your right so walk towards the marsh and turn right onto trampled down reeds to find this sun-baked, orange face.
lines.protection: pad, watch the somewhat uneven landing as this boulder is about as close to the marsh as you can get.

lines.name: Jenn Queen of the Nile
lines.description: Climb arret on the left of the boulder to peak
lines.location: Route is before new Squamish and after the great roof in the area marked as "Talus Field" in old PDF guide.

lines.name: The Journey
lines.description: Located about 40 yards past and just uphill from the Gateway Boulder, this problem is a great "one move wonder" dyno off of small crimps to the lip. The two obvious crimps look better than they feel and you have to use your feet just right to get enough momentum with your left hand to stick the lip.
lines.location: 40 yards past and about 15 yards uphill from the Gateway Boulder.

lines.name: Ken's Super Slab
lines.description: Stand start by carefully pulling onto the slab. Various beta exists to accomplish this, but common beta (and the style of the FA) uses a high right foot at the lip, high right hand on a sharp sidepull that can also be crimped to some degree, and low left hand against the slab to create some tension.    Once your left foot is established, follow the left-trending feature that can be used as a sidepull/undercling for the left hand and gain thin crimps for the right. Technical footwork will bring you to the top of a great slab.
lines.location: Located on the far right of the Nine-tenths boulder on the opposite side of Bullfighter's Friend. If you are following the trail from The Gateway the slab will be almost facing you as you approach Nine-Tenths.

lines.name: Last Meal
lines.description: Stand start on thin but obvious crimps on the right side of the highball boulder. Follow the line of crimps direct, making a series of long movements to gain rounded holds, finishing with a somewhat highball mantel. Creative use of a prominent crimp flake, and more importantly technical footwork will bring success!      Treat the prominent crimp flake (gained with the first move after pulling on) with care, it flexes noticeably on its underside.      I thought this was an excellent technical crimp line, only two stars because of the flexing crimp.
lines.location: Located on the right hand side of the Highball boulder, with the starting crimps a few feet right of Waiting in Line for the Electric Chair.   As with the other problems on this boulder the downclimb is a bit tricky.
lines.protection: pad(s) and a spotter   This problem is not as high as Electric Chair but is fairly sustained near the top and has an angled landing.   The spotter will especially come in handy if the flexing hold decides to snap off.

lines.name: Lost at Sea
lines.description: SDS (carefully) on a finger-jug under the short roof. Using heel and toe trickery to keep body tension move low and right through a series of decent edges. Once established on the highest good edge either move up and slightly right to an interesting crimp/pinch hold before locking off to the lip, or just dyno it out.   Really nice movement on this one and the presence of tepid bog-water under the beginning moves adds a bit of spice to this otherwise ass-dragging problem.      If you would rather not risk a soaker, start standing on the good edge and finish with the pinch move or the dyno. This is "Rescue" and goes at about V1.
lines.location: On the swamp facing side of the West Nile Boulder. Head around the boulder until you find a V shaped indent in the boulder that forms a small overhang on either side. The starting hold for Lost at Sea can be found under the right hand side overhang.      This problem is only really accessible in the early spring before the snow and ice melts, raising the water level of the swamp.
lines.protection: Pad and maybe a tarp depending on the water level.

lines.name: Malaria
lines.description: Start low under a small cave with right hand at the lip (low start is V5). Once you hit the rail you have to match and move out left for the pumpy and awkward lip traverse for which there is multiple beta. Some people try to heel hook and work their way out the lip before the awkward mantle. I campused through this section as my heel felt insecure but either way its hard.      We need some pics of this....
lines.location: Near the pond, obvious roof problem starting low.
lines.protection: Make sure you get a pad low to protect your back from the sharp slab on the opening move.

lines.name: Malaria Low
lines.description: Low start to Malaria.      Start low under a small cave below the high start to Malaria. Get your left heel on or just flag it and use a far right foot well underneath to do the lock off move to the lip. Now finish Malaria.      First move is a bit of a backscratcher with a rock close behind your back. Be careful.
lines.location: Couple pads - one down low because there is a rock behind you that wants to gouge your back.

lines.name: Manteling 101
lines.description: Sit start in the short left facing corner. Climb up to the lip and the easy mantle.Départ assis dans le coin. Grimper sur la bordure et rétablir sur le haut du bloc.
lines.location: Dans le petit coin sur la droite du bloc Gateway

lines.name: Manteling 201
lines.description: Sit start 5 feet left of Manteling 101. Climb up the well featured face then a mantle.Départ assis 5 pieds à côté de Manteling 101. Grimper droit sur la face avec plusieurs bonnes prises et se rétablir sur la vire.
lines.location: Between Put All Your Fears to Rest and Manteling 101Entre Put All Your Fears to Rest et Manteling 101

lines.name: November
lines.description: SDS matched on an obvious flake with decent feet. November moves to the left following the rail feature and incorporating a sharp crimp for the left hand and a potentially painful heel hook. From here a big move will take you to a huge jug at the lip. The topout was cleaned off this past fall, adding some enjoyable moves to get established above the lip.
lines.location: Located under the small roof on the boulder behind and to the left of the Gateway boulder.
lines.protection: A pad and/or a spotter to protect a rock and tree which can become dangers if you swing off or miss the big jug.

lines.name: Orbital Insertion
lines.description: Stand start matched on a flake just under the lip with your choice of a number of slippery edges for feet. Make a few moves up through right facing incut crimps in order to slap to the blunt arete which runs up the centre of the boulder. Finish up the arete as per Orbital Traverse.      A number of options exist to move through the crimps to the arete all of which are somewhat awkward.      It might also be possible to sit start this problem by moving up through the sloping edges that are eventually used for feet. This would be considerably harder than the stand.
lines.location: Starts just under the lip to the right of the blunt arete in the middle of the Orbital Boulder. The Orbital Traverse begins on the far left hand side of this boulder and moves up through blocky corners to the arete. From the arete look down and to the right, the starting flake should be fairly obvious.      The Orbital Boulder is located just to the right of the Tigerlily Boulder, near the end of the main approach trail. From the Highball/Malaria area follow the trail through some jumbled boulders (The Slab and Africa Boulders are found here) for a few minutes. The Tigerlily Boulder is tall and has a prominent ledge running through it.

lines.name: The Orbital Traverse
lines.description: SDS at the lowest point of the left end of the boulder (closest to the Tigerlily Boulder), follow the series of rising, blocky corners until the blunt, sloping arete around the centre. Make moves to edges higher up and roll over the lip, finishing up the low angle slab. The traverse right can be somewhat pumpy if you move slowly with the crux coming at the move to the edges once the underside of the boulder steepens.
lines.location: On the shorter boulder next to the Tigerlily Boulder. The Tigerlily Area is the second last area with established problems if you are following the lower trail along the swamp which begins at The Gateway Boulder. Tigerlily is a very  prominent and aesthetic line and Orbital Traverse stands out as well with its blocky corners.
lines.protection: pad for the crux if desired

lines.name: Pharaohs Peak
lines.description: SDS on left of large crack. Reach up to round nub, traverse right to triangle crimp and gain the upper peak. Avoid arret.
lines.location: Route is before new Squamish and after the great roof in the area marked as "Talus Field" in old PDF guide.

lines.name: Prisoner of Gravity
lines.description: Great line on the backside of the Highball Boulder - start on some high crimps and work your way up a precarious and delicate face. The crux is super cryptic and the feet are horrible at first. I am not going to give away beta here in part because I had to work out the sequence over multiple visits.; )Note...This problem is listed in the online guide as V4. The current consensus (other than the guidebook) is V5/6. I would call it a stout V5+ or V6 (depending on the area). The top moves are not trivial and involve a large dyno with your feet about 10 feet OTD so pad up.

lines.name: Put All Your Fears To Rest
lines.description: SDS/Crouch start along the sloping ledge which runs across the Gateway Boulder. Dyno or deadpoint to the lip and mantel.       This problem can vary greatly in difficulty depending on where you choose to begin, with the most challenging version moving direct through the blankest section of the face about midway along the boulder. As the problem is very short, dynoing this blank section is by far the most satisfying option.
lines.location: On the Gateway Boulder, about midway along the sloping rail which runs across the boulder.

lines.name: Running of the Bulls
lines.description: Climb up the featured face
lines.location: Between the arete and tree in front of you when you arrived by Gateway path

lines.name: Sahara
lines.description: Stand start on the undercling rail and a very high crimp/pinch around the middle of the boulder. Establish your feet then pull up hard on the crimp/pinch in order to reach an assortment of gaston/crimps that seem to be facing the wrong way. From here find somewhere to smear your feet and make a toss for a ledge at the top of the boulder, top out.      The starting undercling recently broke, not really changing the difficulty but potentially leaving this problem even more height dependent with the loss of a foothold. If you are under 5'10" this will probably feel harder than v4.
lines.location: Start around the middle of the Africa Boulder, the (broken) undercling and high crimp/pinch are fairly obvious. The Africa Boulder is found just before the Tigerlily Area if you are following the trail from the Highball area. The boulder is a vertical face with a blank section running through its centre.

lines.name: Scratching Post Direct
lines.description: Stand start on a crimp and a sloping edge around chest height just right of a tree. Move up and right through decent but somewhat hidden holds with some tricky, slick feet.      The original and full line starts on the left arete and traverses into the start holds for the direct version. If you can squeeze past the tree this might still go but doesn't add much value or challenge.
lines.location: On the backside of the Apathy Boulder. The Apathy boulder is opposite the Malaria Boulder and the problem West Nile Direct, it has a scooped face with a decent V0. From the "clearing" walk around on the right or through a tunnel on the left to find the starting holds for this problem in the middle of the boulder.

lines.name: Solid Ether
lines.description: Stand or SDS, either way the starting holds are sidepulls found along the edges of the prominent bulge feature. While both versions require a wide wingspan, the SDS is more height dependent feeling like v4 while the stand is closer to v3.      Squeeze and slap your way upwards using edge sidepulls until high crimps allow for an exit to the right into the depression, or straight up. Heading direct feels less secure and may need a scrub first.
lines.location: Located on the cliff-facing side of the Highball boulder. From "Waiting in Line..." go around the right side of the boulder, this problem is the first you will encounter.      This area is also the common downclimb for the Highball boulder, it is a good idea to get a feel for the problems here before attempting Waiting in Line...
lines.protection: At least one pad is nice, a spotter can protect against the uneven landing further back as well.

lines.name: The Survivalist
lines.description: Left hand start of Electric Chair. Do some hard V4+ moves starting on the left hand side of the boulder that Electric Chair is on. There are some obvious awkward side pulls and poor feet to start. Pull up and into a poor gaston crimp and then cross over your left hand into some bad crimps that are used for the footholds on Electric Chair (V4/5). Now traverse right into Electric Chair, shake out and save some energy for the final left lock-off move on Electric Chair that goes to the lip. Make another move to get to the very top which is a Thank God jug!
lines.location: Lots of pads. I took the fall up around 15 feet in the iron cross section which was wild but fun. A fall on the final moves of Electric Chair would be sketchy but probably ok (?) with enough pads and good spotters.

lines.name: The Sword in the Stone
lines.description: This is a really nice line next to the right of Sahara.Start with two strange underclings and some really awkward splayed feet - one far out left, one on a tiny dimple beneath you. Now pull up into an extremely sharp crimp (the "sword" crimp), get a poor gaston for your right, shuffle your feet a bit and dead point for an obvious pinch crimp up over the lip before slapping the top.The sequence is very aesthetic. A contender for the best V6 in the area.
lines.location: Just before you get to Tiger Lily and Orbital Traverse
lines.protection: Couple pads tops. I used an extra pad wrapped around the tree behind the problem as you can fall into it.

lines.name: Theorem
lines.description: Start with an undercling and your right foot heel hooked on the rail near the start of Gatineau Special. You can get a heel-toe cam thing going. Now do the big left hand move to the crimp at the start of Twisted. Option 1: Match the obvious left hand crimp and finish Twisted as usual (*hard).  Option  2: Right hand to the side pull crimp. Heel hook your left foot onto the rail near the start of Twisted and bump your left hand hard to the good sloper hold at the lip and finish as per Twisted.
lines.location: Sit down start to Twisted by Design.

lines.name: Tigerlily
lines.description: Sit down start, start climbing the left facing dihedral and continue up to top out. There are branches you have to crawl under at the top out.      youtube.com/watch?v=CCJa-eb…
lines.location: The boulder is located at the back of the Calabogie bouldering area. There is a swamp nearyby. You can get down the boulder at the back.

lines.name: Trade Route to India
lines.description: Stand start matched on a good undercling rail with your choice of solid feet. A big move, likely a dyno unless you are particularly tall, leads roughly straight up to an angled, arrow-shaped rail. Match, and head straight up to the lip, this time relying on your rubber for footing.      V4 in the guide, but this grade is "severely height dependent".
lines.location: Located on the Africa Boulder, found along the trail just before the Tigerlily Boulder if you are coming from the Highball area. The boulder is a fairly obvious vertical face with a blank mid section. Trade Route... starts a few feet in from the left arete, wherever the undercling feels best to you.

lines.name: Trench Warfare
lines.description: SDS on the same good flake as "November". Instead of moving to the left up the rail make a stab out right to a small, sharp crimp. As for November the crux comes reaching for a big jug at the lip of the boulder. Once you stick the (rightmost) jug, pull the lip and top out directly up the slab using small crimps and some mantel powers.
lines.location: Located under the small roof on the boulder behind and to the left of the Gateway Boulder.
lines.protection: Same as November, pad and/or spotter to watch for a swing backwards into rocks and a tree.

lines.name: Twisted By Design
lines.description: SDS matched on an obvious crimp just under the lip of a small overhang with a number of options for feet. Make a hard pull over the lip to a uneven ledge, then a series of awkward, bunched cross moves to get established on the arete. Short and tough.      A harder extension begins under the overhang to the right on a hidden undercling and traverses into the starting crimp. This is The Theorem V7.
lines.location: This problem is located on the trail facing arete on the Nine-Tenths boulder. If you are following the trail from the Gateway boulder this is the first problem encountered. The start hold is well chalked for Calabogie and obvious.

lines.name: Waiting in Line for the Electric Chair
lines.description: Super highball line on the backside of Malaria. This line is tall and starts on an obvious set of crimps on the right hand side of the obvious main face of the tall boulder. Beware though as the crux comes at the very end about 17-18 feet OTD - big lock off move. Once you hit the lip with your left hand before to adjust your feet and move again right to the top which is a huge jug...

lines.name: Waterlily
lines.description: Stand start on the lowest point of the prominent ledge which rises up and left into Tigerlily. This eliminates the difficult SDS and opening moves of Tigerlily but retains a big move off the ledge to a sidepull jug and the delicate finishing moves on somewhat hidden edges.       The topout may require some cleaning and care around the branches from a nearby tree. The downclimb should also be done with care as the backside of the boulder is covered in debris and a lot of moss.
lines.location: On the Tigerlily Boulder, the second last area with established problems if following the trail from the Gateway Boulder along the swamp. The starting ledge is obvious.
lines.protection: Pads for the uneven, rocky landing, and a spotter would help confidence as you move off of the juggy rail to smaller holds.

lines.name: West Nile Direct
lines.description: Direct start to the longer West Nile V7ish. SDS matched on a sloping edge underneath the roof. Some start with feet deeper under the short roof, but a more interesting beta involves facing feet outwards and lifting off the ground using a toe hook on a triangular ledge at the lip. Bring hands to feet and continue upwards along the slopey corner and top out.       The full line starting at the far right of the roof section near Malaria traverses along ledges to link up with West Nile Direct. The grade is unconfirmed as far as I know, and beta is unclear at this point.
lines.location: On the far left end of the Malaria Boulder just before the Westward Ho! face. The starting holds (especially the ledge at the lip) should be visible from the clearing which is home to the Highball and Malaria Boulders. Beautiful Odyssey is on the opposite side of this boulder and Malaria is to the right of this problem.
lines.protection: Crash pads under the roof to protect your tailbone from some rock.

lines.name: Westward Ho!
lines.description: Stand start with holds around waist to chest height. Head straight up. The moves get slightly longer as you make your way higher. Highly featured face with interesting colour and some crystal-like holds.
lines.location: Located on one of the swamp-facing sides of the Malaria boulder. Just to the left of West Nile Direct, and around the corner from Beautiful Odyssey. The ground can get a bit wet so watch your feet. Nice view of the swamp from the top on a warm, fall day.

lines.name: Wolf in Sheep's Clothing
lines.description: Start on the far backside of the Chief boulder in a low cave. You can start on the lowest sloping crimp (full value) or the slightly higher rail (original start). Work your way up and out the cave using a big left hand lock off to an ok crimp, deadpoint to a poor half pad sloping right hand crimp that looks unusable then to the lip and awkward mantle.* note - its hard to avoid dabbing on this

lines.name: Yellow Fever
lines.description: SDS matched on the obvious ledge at the lip. Move up over the right of the bulge using sloping holds at the lip. Mantel tenuously over the bulge and top out on a lichen covered slab.       The mantel and top out can seem unlikely, especially with the lichen, but the needed holds are all there and clean.       Essentially this problem is the right exit for West Nile Direct, eliminating the first difficult move to get established on the ledge.
lines.location: Located near the swamp on the Malaria Boulder. Start on the obvious ledge in the West Nile line and head right.
lines.protection: pad for the slightly uneven, rocky landing

lines.name: Secret Garden
lines.description: Up to the ledge, then left to the face.  Coming over the face feels a bit exposed, and looks runout, but once you start the moves, you can see another bolt.  There looks to be another bolt line up to the right, which might be Garden Party, but not certain.
lines.location: Starts at the "C4" painted on the wall.

lines.name: Blood, Sugar, Sex, Magic
lines.description: Upsidedown staircase, very juggy, fun but can be pumpy if you don't shake out where you can!
lines.location: Further to the end (left) of the crag. This climb is beside 5.13b Early Bird.

lines.name: Can You Dig It?
lines.description: Crux is off the ground, one move wonder, follow crack but the climb is very juggy. Shares anchors with 5.9 Chicken of the Sea.
lines.location: First climb as you enter the crag, obvious crackline.

lines.name: Chicken of the Sea
lines.description: Overhanging finger crack, one move wonder, eases off at the top, shares anchors with 5.8 Can You Dig It?
lines.location: When you enter the crag it is on the lefthand side (the Gully is behind it).

lines.name: Classacrack
lines.description: Slightly overhanging, great hand jams to move past crux halfway up.
lines.location: Left side of obvious bulging pillar crack.

lines.name: Corner Route
lines.description: Short corner route, very dirty, probably seldom climbed. A bit of a move 10 feet up which makes a 5.4 grade suspect... But very ledgey, has an airy traverse away from the overhang on really good holds before topping out. There is a good bunch of birch trees to anchor off of at the top and to repel back down.
lines.location: Near the far left end of the crag, very distinct open book corner with a roof.
lines.protection: Standard rack, anchoring gear/slings, no bolts or anchors.

lines.name: Cowvid 19
lines.description: Very fun climb, start is the crux getting off the ground, then fun movement on juggy holds and great feet. Great warm up for other climbs at the crag. Unknown name.
lines.location: As you enter the crag this climb is to the right, the only bolted climb before Cow Crag Canyon (Gully).

lines.name: Dayz of Haze
lines.description: Vertical climb. Will update when I climb it.
lines.location: Next bolted route further left of Roof Pulling/Hand of Fate.

lines.name: Early Bird
lines.description: Short but overhanging, looks difficult.
lines.location: On the left of Blood, Sugar, Sex, Magic.
lines.protection: Bolted with permadraws + anchors. A couple of quickdraws necessary.

lines.name: Fearless Warrior
lines.description: Super classic climb! The crack slightly flares... Awesome movement off laybacks with some good testing holds. One bolt 20 feet up. No anchors. Difficult to protect before the bolt, don't fall!
lines.location: The obvious crackline on the next section of climbing after the Moby Fly wall.
lines.protection: Single rack from .4 to #2. Single bolt, no anchors

lines.name: Generation Next
lines.description: Slightly overhanging route. Will update when I climb it.
lines.location: Farthest bolted route on the left, on its own.

lines.name: Hand of Fate
lines.description: First 5.13 in Ontario! Overhanging.
lines.location: Next section of rock, one of only 2x bolted lines, Hand of Fate is the climb on the right.

lines.name: Moby Fly
lines.description: Classic climb! Short but pumpy. Does not have anchors! Either scramble up the gully and set anchors and drop down over the lip, or top out when you lead it. Sweet movement!
lines.location: Left of the gully as you enter the crag. First fully bolted route.

lines.name: No, Says Nicole
lines.description: Fun, gentle movement.
lines.location: The obvious bulging pillar crack, right line.

lines.name: Roof Pulling
lines.description: Overhanging.
lines.location: Beside Hand of Fate in the next section of rock.

lines.name: Suck on This Dave Smart
lines.description: Gentle ledges until the bulge 2/3 of the way up. Awkward undercling (bad) to a crimp slot, then dyno to the ledge. Feetless climbing on good holds to the top.

lines.name: The Big Cheese Traverse
lines.description: The Big Cheese trav. starts on the south side of the boulder on two blocky holds. Some big opening moves and heels or toes helps do what you have to to match the arete and swing the feet around then head up the west side of the boulder for a nice Topo.
lines.location: Wrapping around the big cheese block

lines.name: Cheese Grater
lines.description: First move is the crux. sit start and pull on the same as "the big cheese traverse" but instead of heading left. head straight up. and Topo.
lines.location: big cheese boulder. same start as big cheese traverse.

lines.name: Straight Cheesin'
lines.description: Straight Cheesin' is just right of "The big cheese traverse." and also just right of the dead tree. Low start in the dihedral work your way up over the lip through a cool half moon sloper pinch then up through the slab onsite smaller edges.
lines.location: Right of the dead tree on "the big cheese block" sit start

lines.name: Papa's Easy Chair
lines.description: Sit start low dow on the arete LH on undercling on the arete and RH undercling under the face. work around the bulge and paddle up through good holds. the first move is the toughest.
lines.location: sit start low left on the arete

lines.name: Cheese Curd
lines.description: sit start low on opposing compression rails. workup to the lip the toss a left heel and pull on a couple heinous crimps to gain the bulge.
lines.location: 10' below the Brea end of big cheese block

lines.name: K9 arete
lines.description: K9 is a low sds on the arete. RH on flat crimp LH on pinch. bust up to a jug then cruise your way to a nice height Topo.
lines.location: on the arete of the k9 boulder

lines.name: The Devils Lettuce
lines.description: The Devils Lettuce is a campus problem at the far left end of the mystery machine face. hang start on obvious pocket jug, power up to the only hold on the face then move through it to the ledgey Topo.
lines.location: left of mystery machine ext left

lines.name: Mystery Machine
lines.description: Stand start in obvious jug pocket. work up through some very nice holds and a shallow dish crux hold. pure line
lines.location: middle of the south face of mystery machine

lines.name: Mystery Machine Ext. Left
lines.description: Mystery Machine left ext starts the same as mystery machine on the jug at the bottom of the face and in the dish pocket. move up and left into the sloper rail stab out left to a good but far pocket. really cool gym like move. almost as cool as the straight up line.
lines.location: same start as MM but heads left to a pocket then up to Topo

lines.name: Scooby Doo
lines.description: Scooby Doo lies around the back side (west) side of the mystery machine block. start on flat ledgey crimps the first move is the toughest blast up to a side pull then back into some solid crimps to the Topo.

lines.name: Those Meddling Kids
lines.description: Those meddling kids is a dyno on the east end of the mystery machine boulder.
lines.location: right (east) face of mystery machine boulder

lines.name: Betty
lines.description: Traverse right on a large block, and move up on decent holds, finishing with a nice view of the park if you peek over the top.
lines.location: The route right of Motor Boat and rightmost bolted route on the island.

lines.name: Dancing in the Dragon's Jaw
lines.description: Diagonal weakness left of Veronica.  Hands on wide crack to the top. Walk off the back.

lines.name: Doin' The Motor Boat
lines.description: The bolted arete on the island's left side when coming down the descent gully. This climb used to be 5.8 until a hold broke, making the start a bit awkward. It's still a good arete climb and worth doing for those breaking into the grade.
lines.location: Start as per Veronica and up the arete.

lines.name: Really Extreme! Ok, Pretty Extreme
lines.description: Crux moves to start leads to a high bolt, easier climbing above.

lines.name: Veronica
lines.description: Left side of the Arete, use it or don't.  Easier if you do, harder if you don't and will seem like a stretched out sandbag if you miss the solution hold and don't check your feet.
lines.location: On the big block, left of the Arete "Doin' The Motorboat"

lines.name: Cold Hands Cold Heart
lines.description: Poorly protected and better avoided climb.

lines.name: The Deceiver (Broken In)
lines.description: Dynamic 3D movement up the steep face.  Old 12+ route, now more like 13c due to a broken hold.

lines.name: The Face That Launched A Thousand Sighs
lines.description: Old school sport on a thin crack system.  Desperate 11 climbing.

lines.name: Formal Ascent
lines.description: Sweet crack on an arch, climb the overhang to anchors.

lines.name: Get Crackin'
lines.description: Follow the short finger crack, move right from ledge and finish on TFTLATS for a better experience.

lines.name: Hyperion
lines.description: Good first 12a route.   hard beginning moves get easier towards the top.

lines.name: Jet
lines.description: Bouldering on an Arete.
lines.location: right of Hyperion on the Arete.

lines.name: Last of the Mul-hicans
lines.description: Short and technical route up the vertical face to a low-angle finish. Has some memorable holds.

lines.name: Mastema's Test
lines.description: Solid for 11a, thorough fight to the anchors.

lines.name: Morning Star
lines.description: Good 5.8 on solid holds. Long route with cool movement.

lines.name: New School tard
lines.description: Poor pro, start on Plumbers and move right around arete instead.

lines.name: Nutcracker
lines.description: Continuous jam crack that angles left up to anchors. Crux near the top through overhang. Super fun! Get on it!
lines.location: Left of the prominent corner crack, crack starts at the top of a ledge.
lines.protection: Standard rack, used cams and nuts. Takes pro everwhere.

lines.name: The Outlier
lines.description: Moderate climbing to a tufa, throw to an anchor splitting the route. Open project extension above(5.14?)

lines.name: Plumbers Do It  With Copper Pipe
lines.description: short awesome crack on a corner that ends on a dirty ledge.  Anchors are up and left from the ledge.

lines.name: Short Man's Dream
lines.description: Great 5.12 climb until the last bolt, the ensuing dyno is the dream.  Throw it.

lines.name: Slaaabtastic
lines.description: Alot like its partner climb to the left, although may seem more difficult for shorter climbers.

lines.name: Sunday Safari
lines.description: Offwidth climbing, easier start into a meaty overhanging excursion.
lines.location: mid route anchors to stop at ledge.

lines.name: Supa Chicane
lines.description: Climb up while trending right, gain the clean headwall and continue to anchors. Long route.
lines.location: First sport route right of the spring.

lines.name: That's Just How The Cookie Crumbles
lines.description: Compression climbing.
lines.location: Left of Last of the Mul-hicans.

lines.name: Wave of the Future
lines.description: Bouldering and intricate body positioning lead to the 6th bolt.  An anchor needs to be installed here to end route and this grade.  The extension is a (5.14-?) open project.
lines.protection: bolts   anchors if your closing a project..

lines.name: Agony of da Feet
lines.description: Climb the flake to a ledge and follow the less than ideal rock to the top.

lines.name: Dancing With the Devil
lines.description: Technical slab, nail a slopey dish crux and boogie down to the anchors.

lines.name: Darcy's Crack
lines.description: On the right side of the crevice, climb the left side of the flake and follow up on pockets.

lines.name: The Happiness Machine
lines.description: Follow the scoopy crimps, perpetually wet and insecure.

lines.name: How Elevators Changed Paris
lines.description: Climb the thin seam, crimp the face, mantle the head.
lines.location: a few bolts after the seam

lines.name: Scarface
lines.description: Small problem on a smaller boulder.  An old bolt shows the way.

lines.name: Squeeze Ur Mout To Da Right An Say Ouin
lines.description: Access the small roof by way of a set of boulder moves.

lines.name: The Argument
lines.description: Fingercrack leads to a face on the left wall.

lines.name: Back Door
lines.description: Wide crack on the right side of the gully.

lines.name: If You Can't Have the Mother, Have the Daughter
lines.description: Stick Clip, crank the pockets on the arete to anchors.

lines.name: Still Waters
lines.description: Face climbing on gear. Exit to the left.

lines.name: Against All Odds
lines.description: Steep V-groove climb that looks insane from the ground.
lines.location: FInd the V groove right of Left hand.

lines.name: Beware the Ginsu
lines.description: Awesome face and arete climbing. Start in the dihedral and work the roof section on thin holds, traverse to the arête and move upward through some thinner holds and a few rest jugs along the way.  Move past a good rest to a few unfavourable slopers towards the bolts on the right for “Left Hand...” get into the small dihedral and some funky moves to the anchor.  FULL VALUE needing a full bag of tricks.  Seldomly done due to its intimidating nature.    A large piece of rock fell off the starting summer 2017, graded 10D but may be closer to 11a for some now.

lines.name: Birthday Cake
lines.description: Start on Dragon leading left to a solid boulder problem crux.

lines.name: Boulevard Circus
lines.description: Nice enjoyable climbing leads to distinct crux midway. Keep your wits about you for the final fun a the end.

lines.name: Caballo Blanco
lines.description: Hard thing climbing on a slightly off vert wall

lines.name: Captain Hook Shuts
lines.description: Awesome moves on an an even awesomer crack.
lines.location: Stick clip first bolt.   bolts   anchors

lines.name: Dragon
lines.description: Route left of the spring.  Follow the roof.

lines.name: Elzinga's Corner
lines.description: Great beginner trad lead, very popular DG route.

lines.name: Facial Rejuvenation
lines.description: Retrobolted 12+.   Rerouted and regraded 5.11 afterwards.

lines.name: Homecoming
lines.description: Easy cruising to an exceptional step move, tricky mantle and overhanging crux finale.

lines.name: The Left Hand of Memnoch
lines.description: Fun traversing of big holds, climb the face leftward to reach anchors shared with Ginsu.  Rated at 11a, a broken hold in 2016 yields a harder climb now.  Again, in June 2018 the bottom on this climb fell off.  Potentially changing grade once again.

lines.name: Naomi James
lines.description: Very poorly protected outing, thin crack and an overhang make for less than ideal pro.

lines.name: Oliver North Face
lines.description: Usually dirty from water run off, sparsely bolted and fully committing.  Don't botch cliping the bolt at the roof, you'll catch some airtime.

lines.name: Spring Cleaning
lines.description: Climb the crack moving right above the spring. Chossy start leads to better rock quality.

lines.name: Track Star
lines.description: Located immediately right of Caballo Blanco, this gem will test your vert skills and problem solving. Highly technical, consistent climbing leads to perfect pocket. Decide which hand goes in it and figure out how to surpass the blank bit beyond. Shake and fire the final boulder problem. One of the best I've bolted at DG.
lines.location: Homecoming Wall - immediately right of Caballo Blanco

lines.name: Valedictorian
lines.description: Lovely climbing on mostly great stone. Sequential climbing leads to a crux midway and a no hands rest. Rest up for the final 20 feet of great movement. Formerly "Naomi James" however the route description for NJ does not line up with this route. A refrigerator sized bloc was removed in the process of establishing this route with little more than a pull. This section of the wall has been cleaned and protected.
lines.location: Homecoming Wall - immediately right of Track Star, left of Homecoming

lines.name: Chitta Locca
lines.description: Retrobolted, start on Mystery and move right.

lines.name: Gwelp
lines.description: sharp and awkward. crux at the anchors. Sandbagged. Need I say more?

lines.name: Iron Maiden
lines.description: Climb a pillar to a crack.

lines.name: Mystery of a Lost History
lines.description: This route had old chopped bolts with origins unknown.   classic for DG. Bouldery and thin.

lines.name: Nifty Nook
lines.description: short overhanging hang crack.  There is an extension of the same grade that goes higher.

lines.name: Riders of the Storm
lines.description: Techy, bring some dyno strength.

lines.name: Soul Food
lines.description: Desperate

lines.name: Tough Day at the Office
lines.description: Lestmost sport route, next to pillar.  Start left of the pillar and traverse up and right,  plenty of horizontals with some big moves along the way.  Climbing may feel easier of you're taller.  A broken hold about halfway up has yielded a more difficult crux.

lines.name: Zoot Suit
lines.description: Hard but good placements.  Climb the lightning bolt 3m left of Tough Day At The Office.

lines.name: Anvil's Away
lines.description: Pull the jugs to the anchors, straight forward climbing.
lines.location: Left of Looney Tunes (5.7) trad route.

lines.name: Asha
lines.description: Like bolted trad, follow the seam up to an overhang.  Pull some moves around it and run it out to the anchors.  Low rock quality beyond the roof means no bolted pro.

lines.name: Fleas & Baboons
lines.description: Start behind the cedar and follow the crack to a roof then move left.

lines.name: It's Raining Volkswagens
lines.description: Climb the corner to a ledge.  Pull the roof to gain a crank then finish the headwall on bolts.  Volkswagen sized blocks were dropped during this routes development, still some left up there.

lines.name: Italian Seasoning
lines.description: Jamming to the top.  Work through some bulges and earn that final clip.

lines.name: Looney Tunes
lines.description: Enjoyable corner.

lines.name: My 7 Factor is 23
lines.description: Climb up the seam and look for a hidden pocket, miss it and get some air time.
lines.location: 3M left of the Looney Tunes corner.

lines.name: The Not So Italian Stallion
lines.description: Alternative left start to Italian Seasoning. Ends on I.S.

lines.name: The Odyssey
lines.description: Amazing face climbing on a longer than expected line.  Epic.   Crux is a technical set of crimps and sidepulls and good footwork to gain a small bassmouth.  Shorter climbers may see the mouth as a deadpoint move.

lines.name: Old Time Zipper
lines.description: Start on a tall block and follow the crack to the roof then move left.

lines.name: Phoo Phoo Wall
